Why can't annotations be used going forward?

Using annotations in the future videos will be much more difficult because they are going to be going over much more complex levels of "abstraction" as she calls it. In this and the previous videos the 'units of discussion' had to do with ones and zeros and those only in pairs at most. The next level of discussion is going to be about arranging groups of eight, sixteen, thirty two and sixty four. Correcting minor errors in the video with annotations will need three or four minutes of reading and that will interrupt the flow of knowledge a person can retain from the video itself. At most I could suggest an annotation that an error is corrected and that it is  explained in detail in the show description. Larger errors would require rewriting and rerecording the entire episode.

Annotations cannot be used in conjunction with the endscreen tool - it's just a limitation of the software. And since annotations don't work on mobile anyway, it's better if we have a place for those corrections and clarifications that are accessible on all devices.

Episode 2: Electronic Computing The globalisation following the early 1900s resulted in an explosion of complexity and data, driving the increasing need for automation and computation. Electro-mechanic computers grew to room-sized machines, prone to errors and expensive to maintain.  Mechanical Relays: The Harvard Mark I was one of the largest electromechanical computers, build in 1944 by IBM. The brains of an electro-mechanical computer where mechanical relays, electronically controlled mechanical switches. These use a control wire containing a coil, producing a magnetic field to control the flow of electricity. Limitations: A downside of mechanical relays is that the mechanical arm can’t move instantly between open and closed states (a good relay could flick 45 times per second). Another limitation was wear and tear; over time things get stuck or fail, and with 35000 relays in the Harvard Mark I, maintenance adds up. Also, the warm and dark environments attracted bugs leading to the first computer bug in 1947, a physical moth found in a relay by Grace Hopper.  Flemings Valve & Vacuum Tubes: A faster and more reliable alternative to mechanical relays was needed, and it came in the form of the Flemings Valve. The Thermionic Valve contained two electrodes in an air-tight glass bulb, this was the first vacuum tube. One electrode could be heated, causing it to emit electrons, the other electrode could then attract those electrons to create the flow of our electric faucet. Any electronic component that permits the one-way flow of current is called a diode. But containing a control electrode, we could permit the flow of electrons. Because of the lack of moving parts, these “vacuum tubes” could switch thousands of times per second. Although they were a huge improvement on mechanical switches, they weren’t perfect. Vacuum tubes were expensive, and still burned out occasionally. This marked the shift from electro-mechanical computing to electronic computing.  The first large scale use of vacuum tubes for computing was the Colossus Mk 1, designed by Tommy Flowers in 1943. It was used to decrypt Nazi communications. This may sound familiar because two years earlier Alan Turning design and electro-mechanical machine called the Turing machine to break Nazi enigma codes called “The Bombe”. The Colossus used 1600 vacuum tubes and is regarded as the first programmable, electronic computer. ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Calculator) completed in 1946 was the first first truly general-purpose programmable computer. It is estimated it completed more arithmetic than humanity before it’s operation. Unfortunately, it required a lot of maintenance with about 50% down time. Vacuum-tube computing was reaching its limits.  Transistors: To reduce cost and size, and to improve reliability and speed, a new electronic switch was needed. In 1947 the transistor was born. A transistor is just like a relay switch which can be opened and closed by applying electrical power via a control wire. Transistors have two electrodes separated by a  material that can sometimes conduct electricity and other times resist it (semi-conductor) , the most common being silicone. The control wire is attached to the gate electrode. By changing the electrical charge of the gate, the conductivity of the semiconducting material can be changed.   Even the first transistors could change states 10,000 times per second. Also, because the transistors are made of solid material, a “solid state component”, they were much more reliable and could be made much smaller than vacuum tubes. Today’s computers use transistors that are smaller than 50 nanometres and can switch states millions of times per second. Most of the semiconductor development happened in the San Jose / San Francisco area leading to the area being nicknamed “Silicone Valley”.

Logic gates have always been interesting to me. Fun fact: the NAND (AND gate leading to a NOT gate) and the NOR (OR gate leading to a NOT gate) gates are universal gates in the sense that every gate can be made up of NAND gates or NOR gates.

In principle, yes. Assuming of course that the time to complete a single operation is the same as for a binary circuit. And in the early days of computers there were indeed non-binary computers. Today you will be hard-pressed to find any non-binary computer except for very exotic applications. However, data storage is often non-binary: For example, you will sometimes find MLCs (multi level cells) in SSDs. As the name suggests, they can not only be in an on/off state, but can take one of many states. And while MLCs can store more data, the access speed and reliability is reduced.

Quick question about the NOT gate.... So the logic is determined by the presence (or lack) of a voltage at the output node, and not the current that flows through it. This output node is the same node as any voltage source which you would be connecting or disconnecting from. Of course if the output is a resistive circuit it will not have as much current flow as the straight down to ground path, but it would still have the same voltage at its input.  It seems like the only way it would work as described is if the output comes after a resistor, because then the voltage would actually drop all the way down (or mostly at least)

This is where "clock" kicks in, all state base electronic componets (not only CPUs) has clock input which triggers logic circuitry to update there states based on current input states, the input change is synced with the clock input, so no input should change in middle. As you may guess clock defines how fast logical circuitry can compute and thats why speeding up CPU clock above recommanded rate is called "overclocking". in digital electronics there no limit clock rate, but limitation of analog electronics and physical world which powers digital electronics set the limit on how much perticilar electronic circutry can handle, the faster clock not only cause part to produce more heat but also state switching can turn in to mess, bits in input might not change state in time before another clock tick, same things happens with handling singals inside CPU, it might start to spew errorus data.

Great episode!  One of the more fascinating logical operations is NOT-AND (or NAND), which is an opposite of AND – it's false only when both inputs are true. This operation is functionally complete, which means you can simulate all other operations using just this one.  Specifically: not A = A nand A A and B = not (A nand B) = (A nand B) nand (A nand B) A or B = not (not A and not B) = (A nand A) nand (B nand B)  Similarly, there is a NOT-OR (or NOR) operation that is also functionally complete. These are the only two binary operations that are functionally complete. AND, OR and XOR are not functionally complete for a simple reason – for false inputs they always give false output, no matter how you connect them, so you cannot simulate negation (NOT) with them. They have to be combined with NOT gate. Both NAND and NOR gates can be used by themselves.

Using annotations in the future videos will be much more difficult because they are going to be going over much more complex levels of "abstraction" as she calls it. In this and the previous videos the 'units of discussion' had to do with ones and zeros and those only in pairs at most. The next level of discussion is going to be about arranging groups of eight, sixteen, thirty two and sixty four. Correcting minor errors in the video with annotations will need three or four minutes of reading and that will interrupt the flow of knowledge a person can retain from the video itself. At most I could suggest an annotation that an error is corrected and that it is  explained in detail in the show description. Larger errors would require rewriting and rerecording the entire episode.

Annotations cannot be used in conjunction with the endscreen tool - it's just a limitation of the software. And since annotations don't work on mobile anyway, it's better if we have a place for those corrections and clarifications that are accessible on all devices.

A good video as always! As a CS major myself, this is actually finally a series where I can answer questions and stuff in the comment section! Just a pedantic note for people who want a little more info:  1) There are also not versions of all the gates. AND, OR, and XOR become NAND, NOR, XNOR, respectively. They are represented by adding a small circle to the end of the gate. While they can be formed just by adding a not gate at the end of the inputs, they are common enough that they get their own specialized parts. You often here people verbally NAND and XNOR when talking about logic, so I think it is interesting to note even though this isn't computer engineering.  2) While by convention in truth tables 1 is true and 0 is false, this is often not the case when we actually look at real components. Because of power usage, the opposite is often used. Generally, the more common output is set to 0.  3) 0 doesn't actually mean nothing is flowing through. For example, we may set our 1 to 5 volts, and our 0 to 2.3 volts. This allows for us to have an "off" state at 0 volts. We wouldn't want our computer to be calculating stuff with 0s when it is off! There are also other uses for this state, but this may be covered in a future video.

Great introduction to Digital Logic. I hope that it was well paced for those who are new to it.  I do have a minor gripe though. Most transistors operate on voltage (think water pressure) and not on current (the flow itself).  Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJTs) do operate on currents but are no longer used for computing. BJTs were the transistors pictured in the episode. In modern computers however, Field Effect Transistors (FETs) are the ones that are actually used and they are used because there is almost no current flowing.  The reason that FETs are so efficient even translates well to the water metaphore. You waste less water with pressure-based logic  because water only has to move when gates are turned on or off whereas with flow-based logic, anything that is on needs to have water flowing to the ground.  Anyways, since the topic of the episode was actually digital logic and not transistors, I understand why they were oversimplified.

I don't know if she'll be covering K-Maps, but I'm almost certain in either the next episode, or the one immediately after that, she'll be building up an adder from logic gates.  For those who like textual education more than visual: for two bits A and B, A + B = "A or B" with a carry of "A and B". This is a half-adder. But then to include the carry bit in the next set of addition for the next bits in binary string, you need to handle 3 bit addition, and for that, you need a full-adder: A + B + C = "A xor B xor C" with a carry of "(A and B) or (A and C) or (B and C)".  With that logic, tada, you can add any two positive integers together! (Negatives require two's compliment representation, which is another step up the ladder of learning, and floating-point [fractional] values are a whole other beast.)

Some things that weren't covered this episode and will probably be covered next is that AND, OR, and XOR are often combined with a NOT on the output resulting in NAND, NOR, and XNOR respectively. In addition, by applying the same wire to both inputs or a NAND or a NOR, it can act as a not. Combine that with a nifty trick that lets you convert between AND and OR by inverting the inputs and outputs, and it becomes possible to define all of the basic logic gates in terms of just NOR or NAND. Anyone who is familiar with Minecraft Redstone knows this in some way as, prior to repeaters and pistons, only OR gates (combining wires) and NOR gates (redstone torch) are available to you. Despite this, people have been able to build entire computers out of just these few elements.
